body: @pulquero I had a quick look around but I can't find any sort of 'official' description of the `spif:dateFormat` function. Is there such a document? In any case - I guess it makes sense that it either uses the platform locale, or the user can somehow _specify_ the locale. It does mean that the test is overly restrictive.

issue.title: Workbench does not support setting the empty prefix

milestone.description: First official release of Eclipse RDF4J

repository.name: rdf4j
repository.description: Eclipse RDF4J: scalable RDF for Java

issue.body:
Inside the Workbench, binding the empty prefix to a namespace causes the definition of a prefix named "namespaces".

This behavior may be determined by a bug in the server-side implementation the [REST API for setting the namespace for prefixes](http://rdf4j.org/doc/the-rdf4j-server-rest-api/#Set_the_namespace_for_a_specific_prefix)

To set the empty prefix, the relevant URL has this form: `http://....../rdf4j-server/repositories/mem-rdf/namespaces/`

(Note that this URL differs from the one for bulk operations on namespaces, which does not end with a trailing slash)

The buggy behavior may be determined by the following piece of code:

https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/releases/2.0.x/core/http/server-spring/src/main/java/org/eclipse/rdf4j/http/server/repository/namespaces/NamespaceController.java#L54

```
String pathInfoStr = request.getPathInfo();
String[] pathInfo = pathInfoStr.substring(1).split("/");
String prefix = pathInfo[pathInfo.length - 1];
```

Based on the documentation of [String.split(String)](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/lang/String.html#split-java.lang.String-),  in case of a path such as ".../mem-rdf/namespaces/", the last element in the array would be "namespaces" (because trailing empty strings are ignored)

body:
http://spinrdf.org/spif

```
On Wednesday, 10 August 2016, 22:16, Jeen Broekstra <notifications@github.com> wrote:
```

 @pulquero I had a quick look around but I can't find any sort of 'official' description of the spif:dateFormat function. Is there such a document? In any case - I guess it makes sense that it either uses the platform locale, or the user can somehow specify the locale. It does mean that the test is overly restrictive. ‚Äî
You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

Can we set the locale for the test by using Locale.setDefault() and restoring it afterwards?

```
On Wednesday, 10 August 2016, 22:16, Jeen Broekstra <notifications@github.com> wrote:
```

 @pulquero I had a quick look around but I can't find any sort of 'official' description of the spif:dateFormat function. Is there such a document? In any case - I guess it makes sense that it either uses the platform locale, or the user can somehow specify the locale. It does mean that the test is overly restrictive. ‚Äî
You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

I found http://spinrdf.org/spif earlier, but  that document does not contain anything about a `spif:dateFormat` function. In fact the only reference to 'dateFormat' I find there is for the `spif:parseDate` function, which is the inverse (creating a dateTime literal from a semi-formatted string).

Thanks, that sounds like a decent short-term fix. I'll tweak the locale in the test to at least make it succeed for @manuelfiorelli . 

But in the longer run I guess we need to take a look at where this function comes from, and whether it should be included in the set of supported spin functions at all.

I am unsure whether a should log a separate bug, but after fetching recent commits I've found another test failing for exactly the same locale-dependent behavior:

```
  <testcase name="testFatalErrorPrologContent" classname="org.eclipse.rdf4j.rio.rdfxml.RDFXMLParserTest" time="0.013">
    <failure message="expected:<[Content is not allowed in prolog]. [line 1, column 1]> but was:<[Il contenuto non √® consentito nel prologo]. [line 1, column 1]>" type="org.junit.ComparisonFailure"><![CDATA[org.junit.ComparisonFailure: expected:<[Content is not allowed in prolog]. [line 1, column 1]> but was:<[Il contenuto non √® consentito nel prologo]. [line 1, column 1]>
    at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:115)
    at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:144)
    at org.eclipse.rdf4j.rio.rdfxml.RDFXMLParserTest.testFatalErrorPrologContent(RDFXMLParserTest.java:137)
]]></failure>
  </testcase>
```

Can I just say it's great to have you on board @manuelfiorelli  - this should keep us on our toes to take proper care of locale issues :) 

I'll take a look at both problems at the same time - even if it is in a different test suite.

@manuelfiorelli That failing test was a test I just added yesterday in pull request #282 so sorry for that regression. It may be easiest to disable that line in RDFXMLParserTest and the equivalent line in TriXParserTest.

issue.title: workarounds in unit tests to account for different platform locales.

repository.name: rdf4j
repository.description: Eclipse RDF4J: scalable RDF for Java

issue.body:
This PR addresses GitHub issue: #280

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:
- SPIN unit tests now force English locale for test execution
- TriX and RDF/XML parser tests do not verify exact error message anymore.

Make sure you've followed the [Contributor Guidelines](https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md). In particular (please tick to indicate you've taken care of it):
- [x] RDF4J code formatting has been applied
- [x] tests are included
- [x] all tests succeed

body: PR up with fixes/workarounds for both issues.

@jeenbroekstra @ansell Following this example, I was able to [skip tests](http://maven.apache.org/surefire/maven-surefire-plugin/examples/skipping-test.html) during the compilation, by executing Maven as follows:

```
mvn install -Dmaven.test.skip=true
```

In fact, I've used the nice checkbox provided by Eclipse.
